item.title: Mac setup (Part 0)
item.description: VPNs, SSH reverse tunnels, Syngergy -> Barrier -> Input Leap, KVMs. I’ve dodged using the Mac for nearly eight years, but now I have to give in. WARNING: This post might seem obvious to many macOS users. Coming from the Linux world of personal computers and having used tiling windows managers for a while now, I always struggle with using Mac OS at work. I don’t like it a single bit.

item.title: GPG + SSH ?
item.description: This will be a small walk through on how to generate an authentication subkey on GPG and integrated with ssh. First of all bare in mind that will need a GPG key first in order to generate this subkey, if have not generated on yet refer to part 0 of these series. Authentication Key In order to generate an authentication key, as I mentioned before, you will need to have a key generated.

item.title: Dealing with your private key
item.description: Now that you’ve managed to create your own GPG key it’s time to understand a bit more about how GnuPG works. The first question we need to ask is where are our keys stored. The answer depends on which version of GnuPG you are running. From version 2.1 onwards the method of storing your keys has change. On previous versions our keys were stored in two separate keyring under the ~/.

item.title: Getting started with GnuPG
item.description: GnuPG is a complete and free implementation of the OpenPGP standard and this is just part 0 of who knows how many series where I will explain my basic understanding of GPG and how useful is on my daily basis. If you wish to understand more in detail how GPG work please refer to the RFC or here is a great post that captures the essence of it quite deeply.
